Socks, "the crazier the better," will be the rule at
the Boosters' Club "Sock Hop," tonight from 9 p.m. to
1 a.m. in the Homewood Gymnasium.
Shoes will be checked at the door and casual dress
will be worn as the couples dance to the music of Brayden
Ridenour's orchestra. This is the second and last all-fraternity rush dance.
Tickets can be purchased on advance sale at $2.25
in the Levering Hall and Dormitory Cafeterias and are
available from any Boosters Club member. They can also
be purchased tonight at the door
for $2.50.

service fraternity, will be handling the checking of shoes and
coats. "Shoes will be sealed in
bags and stamped with tickets,

of checking that has not worked

put the beer kegs on the far

and also to provide mops for any
spillage."
Socks of Paper
Decorations for the dance will
be hundreds of paper socks

prizes will be awarded to persons
wearing the "wildest socks."

rear of the gymnasium.

stated, "We hope everyone will
come and have a good time. The
dance is well planned and should
prove to be enjoyable to all."

Advocates Career Service
"The poor organization of the
Armed Forces" involves "interservice rivalry, morale deterioration, bad pay and a terrific turnover in personnel."
Dr. Long feels that the Selective Service System, which costs
tax-payers "more in the long
run," is not the answer to the
armed forces' personnel problem.
Rather, he advocates a "career
armed force, with higher pay and
increased benefits." He noted
that the present turnover is so
great that the people handling
scientific weapons don't even
know each other, but thinks that
a career armed force would ensure a more effective fighting
team.
Slaps Big Unions, Big Business
Turning to his own field Dr.
Long commented on inflation,
saying, "Arrogant wage-price
policies of big unions and corporations force the government to
institute a tight-money policy."
This, he believes, is not the answer. "A great deal of guts is
required to implement the proper
solution."He suggests, "anti-trust
laws must be applied to both big
corporations and big unions,"
and noted, "the subsidies that
are now paid out to pressure
groups as a result of political
pressure divert needed funds
from our defense spending.. ."

A dynamic personality articulate and coatless lectures, illustrative stories and a Phi Beta
Kappa key are Dr. Long's hallmarks.
He began working at age
eleven, selling newspapers in an
Army camp on the West Coast,
later was a gas station attendant,
saw-mill hand, truck driver,
house - to - house salesman, a
truck farmer in the early 1930's
and also experienced periods of
unemployment.
The forty-nine year old father
of two earned his Bachelor's degree at Washington and Jefferson College, graduating in 1933,
and his doctorate at Princeton
University in 1938. During World
War II, he was a lieutenant in
the United States Navy and has
been at Johns Hopkins since 1946.

her guest at a party weekend?

dollar bills, for example.

doors for him, walk on the traffic- side of the path, assist

know each other, but thinks that

team.

are now paid out to pressure
groups as a result of political
pressure divert needed funds
from our defense spending.. ."

THE PARTY WEEK END:
ITS CAUSE AND CURE
With the season of party weekends almost upon us,
my mail of late has been flooded with queries from young
inmates of women's colleges wishing to know how one
conducts one's self when one has invited a young gentleman for a weekend. This morning, for example, there
were more than 30,000 letters, each containing a lock of
hair. I gave the hair to a bombsight maker and the
lanolin to a dry sheep of my acquaintance, and I turned
instantly to the question: How should a young lady deport herself when she has asked a young gentleman to be
her guest at a party weekend?
Well, my dear girls, the first thing to remember is that
your young gentleman is far from home and frightened.
Put him at his ease. You might, for instance, surprise him
by having his mother sitting in a rocker on the station
platform when he gets off the train.
Next, what kind of corsage should you send your
young gentleman? Well, my beloved maidens, orchids are
always acceptable.
If you find, my esteemed fillies, that your local florist
has run out of stock, do not be dismayed. Make a corsage
out of paper. But pick good,stiff, durable paper—twenty
dollar bills, for example.
Remember at all times, my fond wenches, to show
your young gentleman courtesy and consideration. Open
